newsitem.title: BELGIUM: EU high-tech awards to British, Dane, Finn firms.
newsitem.headline: EU high-tech awards to British, Dane, Finn firms.

text.p: A hand-held scanner that makes three-dimensional computer models, a digital compact hearing aid and an advanced security system for corporate data won the 1996 European Information Technology awards on Tuesday.
European Commission President Jacques Santer presented awards, including a cash prize of 200,000 European currency units ($250,000) each, to designers from Britain, Denmark and Finland.

The awards, sponsored by the European Commission, honour creativity, good business sense and devlopment of products with strong market potential. There were more than 250 entrants from all over Europe.
Britain's winner, 3D Scanners, won with its ModelMaker product, a light-weight, easy-to-use unit that can transform a real object into a three dimensional computer model in seconds.
Danish company Oticon was recognised for DigiFocus, a fully digital hearing aid that is tailored to a person's hearing difficulty using a microchip set as powerful as a desktop computer.

Finland's Data Fellows company was honoured for F-Secure SSH software, described as 'an all-encompassing family of cryptography software for the corporate environment, with military-grade specification.'

Other entries, from the Czech Republic, Slovenia, Poland and Hungary as well as more traditional technology centres such as Germany and Holland, included a face-recognition security system, a taxi-dispatch system and simultaneous translation software for personal computers.
